last_narrative:
You snatch the phone and bolt toward the gates, your heart hammering against your ribs. The young monks shout in alarm, but fortune favors your desperate sprint - their heavy robes and sandals aren't built for pursuit, and years of contemplative life haven't prepared them for chasing fleeing strangers.

You burst through the monastery's wooden gates just as a merchant caravan is departing. The timing couldn't be better - the traders' pack animals and wagons create perfect chaos to hide your escape. You duck behind a loaded ox-cart, gasping as the monks appear at the gates, scanning the crowd with confused expressions.

The caravan master, a weathered man with intelligent eyes, notices your distress but doesn't seem alarmed. "Troubles with the brothers?" he asks in accented but understandable German. "They mean well, but sometimes strangers find their... curiosity overwhelming." His knowing smile suggests this isn't the first time someone has fled the monastery in haste.

Over the following weeks, you integrate yourself into Heinrich's trading company. Your modern medical knowledge proves invaluable when his oxen develop infections and when dysentery strikes the camp. The ibuprofen, carefully rationed and presented as "rare Eastern remedies," establishes your reputation as a healer worth protecting.

Your strange clothes become less conspicuous as you acquire period-appropriate garments through trade. Heinrich appreciates having someone who can read Latin inscriptions and help negotiate with monastery scribes along their route. Your smartphone remains hidden but functional - its offline Wikipedia becomes your secret guide to medieval customs and dangers.

The caravan follows well-established trade routes between monasteries and market towns. You're learning the rhythms of 13th-century commerce while your true identity remains safely concealed among fellow travelers who ask few questions about each other's pasts.

[A] Offer to help Heinrich establish a permanent trading post in one of the larger towns - use your knowledge of future trade routes to suggest profitable locations

[B] Volunteer to serve as the caravan's scribe and translator - monasteries always need documents copied and your literacy could earn steady income

[C] Propose joining a pilgrimage route as a guide for religious travelers - your "healing knowledge" would be valuable for the long journeys to holy sites

conversation_history.content:
This is the player's FIRST era. They just used an experimental time machine in present-day Bay Area
to go back a few days, but the controls malfunctioned and threw them here instead.

They are disoriented, scared, and completely unprepared. Their modern clothes mark them as strange.
They have all the items listed in their INVENTORY - these items ALWAYS travel with them.

Begin the story in World War II - American Home Front (1943, California).

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Describe the MOMENT of arrival - disorientation, sensory details
2. Establish what the player sees, hears, smells immediately
3. Show the era's reality through details, not exposition
4. Create an immediate situation requiring response
5. Give the player character a name appropriate to how locals might interpret them
6. End with 3 choices

CHOICE DESIGN:
- All choices must be viable survival paths - no "give up" options
- At least ONE choice should reward understanding of THIS specific era
  (local customs, religion, social hierarchy, what outsiders could offer)
- The historically-informed choice should feel clever to someone who knows the era

TIME PACING: The arrival scene happens over the first few hours/day. Each subsequent turn 
will represent about 6-8 WEEKS (7 turns = 1 year). The travel window will stay closed for 
most of the first year, giving time to establish a life here.

FORMAT:
- 2-3 paragraphs of arrival narrative
- Then present choices on their own lines:

[A] First choice
[B] Second choice  
[C] Third choice

Keep under 300 words. Drop them right into it.

The world tears apart like wet paper.

You stumble forward, legs buckling as reality reassembles around you. The acrid smell of coal smoke and hot metal hits your nostrils. Factory whistles shriek in the distance. Your jeans and hoodie feel impossibly foreign against your skin as you steady yourself against a wooden fence, splinters catching the strange fabric.

A woman in a floral dress and victory rolls stops dead on the sidewalk, staring. Her red lipstick forms a perfect O of shock. Behind her, a man in suspenders and a fedora squints at you like you're speaking German. "What in Sam Hill are you wearing, son?" 

Your phone buzzes in your pocket - 3:47 PM, March 15, 1943. A "Buy War Bonds!" poster stares down from a telephone pole, Uncle Sam's finger pointed directly at your chest. The woman whispers to her companion, and you catch fragments: "...strange clothes..." "...draft dodger maybe..." "...call the authorities..."

More people are noticing. A group of factory workers heading home pause to gawk. Someone mentions your "queer haircut." The woman starts walking toward what looks like a police call box on the corner.

You need to move. Now.

[A] Approach the factory workers directly - claim you're new in town looking for work and got your luggage stolen, explaining your strange clothes

[B] Duck into the nearby diner and try to blend in while figuring out your next move - order coffee and listen to local conversation  

[C] Tell people you're a merchant sailor whose ship just docked - you've been at sea so long you grabbed whatever clothes you could find, and you're looking to buy proper American clothes with your pay

You stride toward the factory workers, forcing confidence into your voice. "Hey there - I'm new in town, looking for work. Had my luggage stolen right off the train."

The eldest worker, a man with grease-stained coveralls and suspicious eyes, looks you up and down. "Stolen luggage don't explain clothes like that, son. What kind of fabric is that?" He reaches out to touch your hoodie's synthetic blend. "Never seen nothing like it."

"And that haircut," mutters another. "You sure you ain't some kind of foreign agitator?"

The situation spirals quickly. Someone mentions the FBI. Another suggests you might be a German spy - after all, saboteurs are a real threat to the war effort. Your strange materials and odd appearance mark you as dangerously different. The crowd grows hostile.

You back away as they start shouting questions about your draft status, your citizenship, where exactly you came from. The woman from earlier returns with a police officer in tow, pointing directly at you.

Over the following weeks, you barely stay ahead of suspicion. You find temporary shelter in a boarding house on the wrong side of town, paying with coins that pass inspection but telling conflicting stories about your background. The factory jobs all require references you don't have. Your modern items stay hidden, but food runs low. War rationing means even basic meals are expensive, and your lack of ration cards draws attention.

The other boarders whisper about you. Mrs. Chen, the Chinese landlady, seems sympathetic but wary. You've managed to survive, but you're still an outsider looking in.

[A] Volunteer for the most dangerous factory job available - prove your loyalty through willingness to risk your life for the war effort

[B] Approach the local Catholic church and claim you're seeking sanctuary after fleeing religious persecution overseas - priests often help displaced people

[C] Seek out the Japanese American families being processed for internment - offer to help them hide valuables or carry messages, knowing they need allies

You approach St. Mary's Catholic Church on a gray morning, its Gothic spires cutting through the industrial smog. Father O'Brien, a weathered Irishman with kind eyes, listens as you speak of persecution, of fleeing terrible circumstances you can't fully explain. 

Your story resonates more than expected. "Aye, I've heard worse tales from the refugees coming through," he nods gravely. "The Nazis have driven many faithful from their homes." He doesn't press for details about which country or which persecution - in 1943, there are too many to choose from.

The church becomes your sanctuary. Father O'Brien introduces you as "Michael" - a good Catholic name for someone seeking a fresh start. The parish community, desperate to prove their patriotism and Christian charity, embraces you warmly. Mrs. Kowalski brings you her late husband's work clothes. The Rosetti family shares their Sunday dinner. You help with church maintenance, and your Swiss Army knife's precision tools make you invaluable for repairs.

Over the following weeks, your position solidifies. Father O'Brien arranges legitimate work papers through the diocese's refugee assistance program. You find steady employment at Sullivan's Metalworks, contributing to aircraft production. The parish women cluck over your thin frame, constantly offering food despite rationing. Your mysterious past becomes romantic rather than suspicious - a brave soul who escaped Hitler's persecution to fight for freedom.

The other boarders at Mrs. Chen's now nod respectfully when you pass. You're no longer the strange outsider, but "poor Michael who survived terrible things overseas." Your ibuprofen has helped several parishioners with chronic pain, cementing your reputation as blessed with healing hands.

As summer approaches, Father O'Brien pulls you aside after evening mass. "Michael, my boy, there's something I need to discuss with you."

[A] Offer to teach basic medical knowledge to the parish women - your "traditional remedies" could help with wartime shortages of doctors

[B] Volunteer to help write letters for families whose sons are overseas - your education and careful handwriting would be valuable

[C] Propose starting a parish victory garden using advanced agricultural techniques you claim to have learned in the old country

"I could teach the women some... traditional remedies," you tell Father O'Brien carefully. "Basic healing knowledge from the old country."

His eyes light up. "Ah, that would be a godsend, Michael. With so many of our boys overseas and doctors scarce..." He arranges for you to meet with the Ladies' Auxiliary after their next meeting.

The first session goes well. You demonstrate proper wound cleaning, explain the importance of boiling water, show how to recognize infection. Mrs. Kowalski nods knowingly - "My grandmother used to say the same things." But complications arise when you mention aspirin alternatives and pain management.

"Where exactly did you learn this, dear?" asks Mrs. Henderson, the banker's wife and unofficial leader of the group. "It sounds almost... medical. Like what they teach in nursing school." Her tone sharpens. "You're not claiming to be a doctor, are you? Because practicing medicine without a license is illegal, especially for..." She doesn't finish, but her meaning is clear.

Over the following weeks, word spreads about your "healing knowledge." Some women are grateful - your advice helped Mrs. Chen's arthritis and young Tommy Rosetti's infected cut. But others whisper about unlicensed practice and foreign remedies. Dr. Brennan, the elderly parish doctor, starts asking pointed questions about your training.

The situation becomes delicate when Mrs. Sullivan's baby develops a fever. She comes to you first instead of calling the doctor, trusting your "blessed hands" more than expensive medical bills. You give her basic advice and one precious ibuprofen tablet, crushed and dissolved. The baby recovers quickly, but Dr. Brennan hears about the "miracle cure" you provided.

As autumn arrives, Father O'Brien warns you quietly: "The doctor's been asking questions, Michael. He's not hostile, but he's... curious about your methods."

[B] Redirect your reputation by claiming your healing gift comes from prayer and faith - emphasize the spiritual rather than medical aspect

[C] Volunteer to join the Red Cross as a civilian aide - your "overseas experience" with trauma victims would be valuable for casualty preparation

You kneel in the empty confessional booth, your voice barely above a whisper. "Father, I need to tell you the truth. My name isn't Michael, and I... I haven't been honest about my past."

Father O'Brien's silhouette shifts behind the screen. "Go on, my son."

"I can't explain how I got here - you wouldn't believe me if I tried. But I'm not a spy or saboteur. Everything I've done, helping people, the healing knowledge... it all comes from a genuine desire to do good." Your voice cracks. "I just wanted to belong somewhere."

The priest is quiet for a long moment. When he speaks, his tone is careful but not unkind. "I suspected something, lad. Your knowledge, your way of speaking... But I've seen your heart. The question is - what are we to do about it?"

Over the following weeks, Father O'Brien becomes your cautious ally, but the situation remains precarious. He can't lie to authorities directly, but he begins deflecting questions about your past with careful words about "the sanctity of confession" and "protecting those who seek sanctuary." His support buys you time, but doesn't eliminate the suspicion.

Mrs. Whitfield's investigation continues, though Father O'Brien's intervention slows it. The parish community remains divided - some still trust you based on your good works, others whisper about deception. Your position at the metalworks grows shakier as background checks intensify.

The winter cold seeps through the boarding house walls. Mrs. Chen, sensing the tension, raises your rent. Your carefully built life feels increasingly fragile, held together by Father O'Brien's protection and the fading goodwill of people you've genuinely helped.

As 1944 approaches, Father O'Brien meets you after midnight mass. "Michael - or whatever your name truly is - I've bought us some time, but not much. We need a plan."

[B] Propose that you "remember" more details about your past under his spiritual guidance - create a believable backstory that explains your knowledge

[C] Suggest you publicly confess to being a deserter who fled in cowardice but found God - frame your deception as shame over military dishonor rather than foreign origins

"Father, I think... with your guidance, prayer, I might remember more. The trauma, it's blocked so much." You meet his eyes through the confessional screen. "Help me piece together what happened."

Father O'Brien proves surprisingly adept at crafting your new history. Together, you construct the story of Mikhail Kowalsky - a Polish medical student whose family was killed in the Warsaw Ghetto uprising. The trauma caused selective amnesia, explaining your gaps in memory. Your medical knowledge comes from interrupted university studies. Your strange arrival stems from months of wandering after escaping a work camp.

The timing proves fortuitous. News of the Warsaw Ghetto uprising has just reached American newspapers, generating tremendous sympathy for Polish survivors. Father O'Brien presents your "recovered memories" to Mrs. Whitfield as a breakthrough achieved through spiritual counseling and prayer - a miracle of faith healing psychological wounds.

Over the following weeks, your story gains credibility. The Polish families in the parish embrace you as a survivor of unimaginable horror. Mrs. Kowalski weeps when she hears your "memories" of her homeland's suffering. Dr. Brennan, moved by your tragic backstory, offers to help you complete medical training through a refugee assistance program.

The Red Cross investigation transforms from suspicion to sympathy. Mrs. Whitfield, now viewing you as a heroic survivor rather than a security risk, fast-tracks your application. Your "trauma-induced amnesia" explains every inconsistency in your earlier statements.

Your position strengthens dramatically. Sullivan promotes you at the metalworks after hearing your story. The parish ladies compete to care for "poor Mikhail who lost everything." Even the suspicious Mrs. Henderson now speaks of you as "that brave Polish boy who escaped the Nazis."

As spring arrives in 1944, Father O'Brien smiles during confession. "God works in mysterious ways, Mikhail. Your new life is taking root."

[B] Propose starting a support group for other refugees and trauma survivors - build a community of displaced persons

[C] Volunteer to help with war bond drives using your story as inspiration - become a public speaker for the war effort

Your talks raise steady money for the war effort - not spectacular amounts, but respectable contributions that help quota goals. The speaking circuit becomes routine. You develop polished anecdotes, learn to pace emotional moments, understand which details move different audiences. Factory workers respond to stories of Nazi labor camps. Church groups connect with accounts of faith sustaining hope. Mothers relate to your grief over lost family.

As summer deepens in 1944, your reputation as "the Polish speaker" spreads beyond the immediate area. Other parishes request your testimony. The county war bond committee adds you to their regular roster. You're becoming a minor local celebrity - recognized at the grocery store, greeted warmly on the street.
